AI.motivation: To overcome the key limitation of behavioral cloning (BC) where agents struggle to recover from unseen situations due to reliance on expert demonstrations only for visited states.
AI.method: The authors propose learning to search (L2S) with expert demonstrations, leveraging components like world and reward models for test-time planning and recovery without additional human corrections.
AI.result: Across several visual manipulation tasks, SAILOR demonstrates superior performance compared to state-of-the-art BC methods, including BC models trained on considerably larger datasets.
AI.conclusion: SAILOR can effectively identify nuanced failures, avoid reward hacking, and perform robust imitation learning by reasoning independently in diverse scenarios. It represents a significant advancement over BC approaches.

title: Towards Network Data Analytics in 5G Systems and Beyond
comment:
Submitted to XLIII BRAZILIAN SYMPOSIUM ON TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND
  SIGNAL PROCESSING - SBrT 2025
summary:
Data has become a critical asset in the digital economy, yet it remains
underutilized by Mobile Network Operators (MNOs), unlike Over-the-Top (OTT)
players that lead global market valuations. To move beyond the commoditization
of connectivity and deliver greater value to customers, data analytics emerges
as a strategic enabler. Using data efficiently is essential for unlocking new
service opportunities, optimizing operational efficiency, and mitigating
operational and business risks. Since Release 15, the 3rd Generation
Partnership Project (3GPP) has introduced the Network Data Analytics Function
(NWDAF) to provide powerful insights and predictions using data collected
across mobile networks, supporting both user-centric and network-oriented use
cases. However, academic research has largely focused on a limited set of
methods and use cases, driven by the availability of datasets, restricting
broader exploration. This study analyzes trends and gaps in more than 70
articles and proposes two novel use cases to promote the adoption of NWDAF and
explore its potential for monetization.

AI.tldr: Mobile Network Operators (MNOs) underuse data compared to OTT players. This paper reviews NWDAF adoption, identifies research gaps, and proposes new use cases.
AI.motivation: To help MNOs better utilize data analytics, unlock new opportunities, reduce operational risks, and compete more effectively with OTT players.
AI.method: Analyzed over 70 research papers related to NWDAF, examined existing applications, and proposed two new use cases to expand its adoption and monetization.
AI.result: Identified academic trends and gaps in NWDAF research and introduced use cases that enhance NWDAF’s utility for MNOs, promoting wider adoption.
AI.conclusion: NWDAF could be strategically impactful for MNOs by improving data utilization, boosting efficiency, and offering monetization opportunities beyond connectivity services.

title: Power Law Guided Dynamic Sifting for Efficient Attention
summary:
Efficient inference on GPUs using large language models remains challenging
due to memory bandwidth limitations, particularly during data transfers between
High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) and SRAM in attention computations. Approximate
attention methods address this issue by reducing computational and memory
overhead but often rely on expensive top-$k$ operations, which perform poorly
on GPUs. We propose SiftAttention, a novel approximate attention method that
replaces the top-$k$ step with a computationally efficient element-wise
filtering operation based on a threshold value. Our intuition for doing this is
based on our empirical observation that the $\tau$-th quantile of attention
scores follows a predictable power-law over sequential generation steps.
Exploiting this insight, our approach dynamically estimates a threshold value
per prompt at each generation step. Only attention scores above this threshold
and their corresponding value vectors are loaded/used to compute the attention
output, reducing data movement between HBM and SRAM. Our evaluation
demonstrates that SiftAttention preserves model quality better than existing
approximate attention methods while reducing memory bandwidth usage when
loading value vectors.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SiftAttention, an efficient approximate attention mechanism for large language models on GPUs that reduces memory use by dynamically estimating a threshold, bypassing expensive top-k operations.
AI.motivation: Large language models on GPUs face challenges due to memory bandwidth constraints, especially in attention computations. Existing methods reduce overhead but are computationally inefficient on GPUs.
AI.method: The authors propose SiftAttention, which uses an element-wise filtering operation based on a dynamically estimated threshold value instead of top-k computations, exploiting predictable patterns in attention score quantiles.
AI.result: SiftAttention reduces memory bandwidth usage during value vector loading while maintaining model quality better than other approximate attention methods.
AI.conclusion: SiftAttention offers a GPU-efficient, memory-saving approach for approximate attention that outperforms existing methods in maintaining model quality.

title: Learning normalized image densities via dual score matching
summary:
Learning probability models from data is at the heart of many machine
learning endeavors, but is notoriously difficult due to the curse of
dimensionality. We introduce a new framework for learning \emph{normalized}
energy (log probability) models that is inspired from diffusion generative
models, which rely on networks optimized to estimate the score. We modify a
score network architecture to compute an energy while preserving its inductive
biases. The gradient of this energy network with respect to its input image is
the score of the learned density, which can be optimized using a denoising
objective. Importantly, the gradient with respect to the noise level provides
an additional score that can be optimized with a novel secondary objective,
ensuring consistent and normalized energies across noise levels. We train an
energy network with this \emph{dual} score matching objective on the ImageNet64
dataset, and obtain a cross-entropy (negative log likelihood) value comparable
to the state of the art. We further validate our approach by showing that our
energy model \emph{strongly generalizes}: estimated log probabilities are
nearly independent of the specific images in the training set. Finally, we
demonstrate that both image probability and dimensionality of local
neighborhoods vary significantly with image content, in contrast with
traditional assumptions such as concentration of measure or support on a
low-dimensional manifold.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new framework for learning normalized energy models to address challenges in high-dimensional probability modeling, achieving state-of-the-art results on ImageNet64.
AI.motivation: Learning probability models is core to machine learning but is challenging due to high-dimensional data complexities, motivating the need for better approaches.
AI.method: Modified score network architecture to compute energies, with a dual score matching objective optimizing gradients across noise levels, validated on ImageNet64.
AI.result: Comparable cross-entropy performance to state-of-the-art methods; strong generalization evidenced by independence from training set images.
AI.conclusion: The approach robustly models probabilities, revealing unexpected content-dependent variations in probabilities and data dimensionality, challenging traditional assumptions.

title: LSM-2: Learning from Incomplete Wearable Sensor Data
comment:
Xu and Narayanswamy are co-first authors. McDuff and Liu are co-last
  authors
summary:
Foundation models, a cornerstone of recent advancements in machine learning,
have predominantly thrived on complete and well-structured data. Wearable
sensor data frequently suffers from significant missingness, posing a
substantial challenge for self-supervised learning (SSL) models that typically
assume complete data inputs. This paper introduces the second generation of
Large Sensor Model (LSM-2) with Adaptive and Inherited Masking (AIM), a novel
SSL approach that learns robust representations directly from incomplete data
without requiring explicit imputation. AIM's core novelty lies in its use of
learnable mask tokens to model both existing ("inherited") and artificially
introduced missingness, enabling it to robustly handle fragmented real-world
data during inference. Pre-trained on an extensive dataset of 40M hours of
day-long multimodal sensor data, our LSM-2 with AIM achieves the best
performance across a diverse range of tasks, including classification,
regression and generative modeling. Furthermore, LSM-2 with AIM exhibits
superior scaling performance, and critically, maintains high performance even
under targeted missingness scenarios, reflecting clinically coherent patterns,
such as the diagnostic value of nighttime biosignals for hypertension
prediction. This makes AIM a more reliable choice for real-world wearable data
applications.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces LSM-2 with Adaptive and Inherited Masking (AIM), an SSL model for robust representation learning directly from incomplete wearable sensor data without imputation.
AI.motivation: Wearable sensor data often suffers from significant missingness, which challenges traditional self-supervised learning models reliant on complete and well-structured data.
AI.method: AIM utilizes learnable mask tokens to model missingness, both inherent and artificially introduced, enabling robust inference on fragmented real-world data.
AI.result: LSM-2 with AIM achieves top performance across classification, regression, and generative modeling tasks and excels under clinically relevant missingness scenarios.
AI.conclusion: LSM-2 with AIM is a reliable choice for real-world wearable sensor applications, demonstrating scalability and high performance in handling incomplete data scenarios.

title: Seeing the Invisible: Machine learning-Based QPI Kernel Extraction via Latent Alignment
summary:
Quasiparticle interference (QPI) imaging is a powerful tool for probing
electronic structures in quantum materials, but extracting the single-scatterer
QPI pattern (i.e., the kernel) from a multi-scatterer image remains a
fundamentally ill-posed inverse problem. In this work, we propose the first
AI-based framework for QPI kernel extraction. We introduce a two-step learning
strategy that decouples kernel representation learning from
observation-to-kernel inference. In the first step, we train a variational
autoencoder to learn a compact latent space of scattering kernels. In the
second step, we align the latent representation of QPI observations with those
of the pre-learned kernels using a dedicated encoder. This design enables the
model to infer kernels robustly even under complex, entangled scattering
conditions. We construct a diverse and physically realistic QPI dataset
comprising 100 unique kernels and evaluate our method against a direct one-step
baseline. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach achieves
significantly higher extraction accuracy, and improved generalization to unseen
kernels.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces an AI-based framework to extract single-scatterer quasiparticle interference (QPI) patterns, solving an ill-posed problem in quantum material imaging with high accuracy.
AI.motivation: Extracting single-scatterer QPI patterns from multi-scatterer images is a challenging, fundamental inverse problem in the study of quantum materials. Current methods struggle to address the complexity and precision required in this task.
AI.method: The authors propose a two-step AI framework involving a variational autoencoder (VAE) to learn latent representations of QPI kernels, followed by a decoder to align multi-scatterer observations with the pre-learned kernel representations. This design separates kernel learning and inference stages for enhanced robustness.
AI.result: The proposed method achieved higher accuracy compared to a direct baseline and showed improved generalization to previously unseen scattering kernels. The evaluation utilized a diverse, physically realistic dataset consisting of 100 unique QPI kernels.
AI.conclusion: The work presents a significant advancement in QPI imaging by enabling reliable, robust extraction of single-scatterer patterns under complex scattering conditions, paving the way for deeper insights into quantum materials.

title: Exploring Diffusion Transformer Designs via Grafting
summary:
Designing model architectures requires decisions such as selecting operators
(e.g., attention, convolution) and configurations (e.g., depth, width).
However, evaluating the impact of these decisions on model quality requires
costly pretraining, limiting architectural investigation. Inspired by how new
software is built on existing code, we ask: can new architecture designs be
studied using pretrained models? To this end, we present grafting, a simple
approach for editing pretrained diffusion transformers (DiTs) to materialize
new architectures under small compute budgets. Informed by our analysis of
activation behavior and attention locality, we construct a testbed based on the
DiT-XL/2 design to study the impact of grafting on model quality. Using this
testbed, we develop a family of hybrid designs via grafting: replacing softmax
attention with gated convolution, local attention, and linear attention, and
replacing MLPs with variable expansion ratio and convolutional variants.
Notably, many hybrid designs achieve good quality (FID: 2.38-2.64 vs. 2.27 for
DiT-XL/2) using <2% pretraining compute. We then graft a text-to-image model
(PixArt-Sigma), achieving a 1.43x speedup with less than a 2% drop in GenEval
score. Finally, we present a case study that restructures DiT-XL/2 by
converting every pair of sequential transformer blocks into parallel blocks via
grafting. This reduces model depth by 2x and yields better quality (FID: 2.77)
than other models of comparable depth. Together, we show that new diffusion
model designs can be explored by grafting pretrained DiTs, with edits ranging
from operator replacement to architecture restructuring. Code and grafted
models: https://grafting.stanford.edu

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method called grafting to study and edit pretrained diffusion transformers for testing new model architectures efficiently with minimal compute overhead.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to address the challenge of costly pretraining required to evaluate the impact of architectural decisions in model design, inspired by the concept of building new software on existing code.
AI.method: They propose the grafting approach, which involves editing pretrained diffusion transformers to create new architectures. They construct a testbed and explore hybrid designs by modifying operators (e.g., softmax attention) and restructuring architectures.
AI.result: The grafted models demonstrate comparable or improved performance with significantly lower compute requirements (e.g., FID 2.38-2.64 vs. 2.27 for the baseline) and achieve speedup with minimal trade-offs in quality.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights that pretrained models can be effectively used to explore and validate new architectural designs, reducing the cost and barriers to experimentation in model development.

title: Deep Learning-Based Breast Cancer Detection in Mammography: A Multi-Center Validation Study in Thai Population
summary:
This study presents a deep learning system for breast cancer detection in
mammography, developed using a modified EfficientNetV2 architecture with
enhanced attention mechanisms. The model was trained on mammograms from a major
Thai medical center and validated on three distinct datasets: an in-domain test
set (9,421 cases), a biopsy-confirmed set (883 cases), and an out-of-domain
generalizability set (761 cases) collected from two different hospitals. For
cancer detection, the model achieved AUROCs of 0.89, 0.96, and 0.94 on the
respective datasets. The system's lesion localization capability, evaluated
using metrics including Lesion Localization Fraction (LLF) and Non-Lesion
Localization Fraction (NLF), demonstrated robust performance in identifying
suspicious regions. Clinical validation through concordance tests showed strong
agreement with radiologists: 83.5% classification and 84.0% localization
concordance for biopsy-confirmed cases, and 78.1% classification and 79.6%
localization concordance for out-of-domain cases. Expert radiologists'
acceptance rate also averaged 96.7% for biopsy-confirmed cases, and 89.3% for
out-of-domain cases. The system achieved a System Usability Scale score of
74.17 for source hospital, and 69.20 for validation hospitals, indicating good
clinical acceptance. These results demonstrate the model's effectiveness in
assisting mammogram interpretation, with the potential to enhance breast cancer
screening workflows in clinical practice.

AI.tldr: The study develops a deep learning system using modified EfficientNetV2 for breast cancer detection, achieving high accuracy in identifying and localizing lesions and demonstrating strong agreement with radiologists.
AI.motivation: The motivation of the paper is to enhance mammogram interpretation accuracy and automate breast cancer detection to improve clinical workflows and support radiologists.
AI.method: The study employs a modified EfficientNetV2 architecture with enhanced attention mechanisms, validated across three datasets, focusing on lesion localization metrics and clinical concordance.
AI.result: The model achieved high AUROC scores (0.89, 0.96, 0.94) across datasets, consistent concordance rates with radiologists for classification (83.5% to 78.1%) and localization (84.0% to 79.6%), and high usability and acceptance scores.
AI.conclusion: The proposed system shows significant potential in improving breast cancer screening workflows by reliably assisting in mammogram interpretation and supporting clinical decision-making.

title: Artificial Intelligence Should Genuinely Support Clinical Reasoning and Decision Making To Bridge the Translational Gap
summary:
Artificial intelligence promises to revolutionise medicine, yet its impact
remains limited because of the pervasive translational gap. We posit that the
prevailing technology-centric approaches underpin this challenge, rendering
such systems fundamentally incompatible with clinical practice, specifically
diagnostic reasoning and decision making. Instead, we propose a novel
sociotechnical conceptualisation of data-driven support tools designed to
complement doctors' cognitive and epistemic activities. Crucially, it
prioritises real-world impact over superhuman performance on inconsequential
benchmarks.

AI.tldr: The paper highlights a translational gap that limits AI's impact in medicine, proposing a sociotechnical approach to complement doctors rather than focusing on superhuman AI benchmarks.
AI.motivation: The authors seek to address the translational gap that restricts AI's practical adoption in medicine by critiquing technology-centric approaches that often fail to align with clinical reasoning and decision making.
AI.method: They propose a novel sociotechnical framework for designing AI systems that work collaboratively with doctors, emphasizing alignment with real-world diagnostic workflows rather than surpassing benchmarks.
AI.result: The suggested approach focuses on integrating AI systems to enhance doctors' cognitive and reasoning activities while minimizing the incompatibility with clinical practices.
AI.conclusion: Revolutionizing the role of AI in medicine requires focusing on real-world impact and operational compatibility with clinical decision-making instead of prioritizing technological capabilities alone.

title: What does making money have to do with crime?: A dive into the National Crime Victimization survey
summary:
In this short article, I leverage the National Crime Victimization Survey
from 1992 to 2022 to examine how income, education, employment, and key
demographic factors shape the type of crime victims experience (violent vs
property). Using balanced classification splits and logistic regression models
evaluated by F1-score, there is an isolation of the socioeconomic drivers of
victimization "Group A" models and then an introduction of demographic factors
such as age, gender, race, and marital status controls called "Group B" models.
The results consistently proves that higher income and education lower the odds
of violent relative to property crime, while men younger individuals and racial
minorities face disproportionately higher violentcrime risks. On the geographic
spectrum, the suburban models achieve the strongest predictive performance with
an accuracy of 0.607 and F1 of 0.590, urban areas benefit from adding education
and employment predictors and crime in rural areas are still unpredictable
using these current factors. The patterns found in this study shows the need
for specific interventions like educational investments in metropolitan
settings economic support in rural communities and demographicaware prevention
strategies.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes how socioeconomic and demographic factors influence the type of crime victims experience, revealing distinct patterns across urban, suburban, and rural areas.
AI.motivation: To understand how socioeconomic and demographic factors shape the type and risk of crime (violent vs property) for victims, aiming for targeted interventions and prevention strategies.
AI.method: Utilized the National Crime Victimization Survey (1992–2022), balanced classification splits, and logistic regression models evaluated via F1-score. Examined models isolating socioeconomic factors (Group A) and adding demographic controls (Group B).
AI.result: Higher income and education lower violent crime risks; young men and racial minorities are disproportionately affected by violent crime. Suburban models perform best (accuracy: 0.607, F1: 0.590), while rural crime remains unpredictable.
AI.conclusion: The study underscores the need for tailored interventions—educational investments in cities, economic support in rural areas, and demographic-focused crime prevention measures.

title: ChemReservoir -- An Open-Source Framework for Chemically-Inspired Reservoir Computing
summary:
Reservoir computing is a type of a recurrent neural network, mapping the
inputs into higher dimensional space using fixed and nonlinear dynamical
systems, called reservoirs. In the literature, there are various types of
reservoirs ranging from in-silico to in-vitro. In cheminformatics, previous
studies contributed to the field by developing simulation-based chemically
inspired in-silico reservoir models. Yahiro used a DNA-based chemical reaction
network as its reservoir and Nguyen developed a DNA chemistry-inspired tool
based on Gillespie algorithm. However, these software tools were designed
mainly with the focus on DNA chemistry and their maintenance status has limited
their current usability. Due to these limitations, there was a need for a
proper open-source tool. This study introduces ChemReservoir, an open-source
framework for chemically-inspired reservoir computing. In contrast to the
former studies focused on DNA-chemistry, ChemReservoir is a general framework
for the construction and analysis of chemically-inspired reservoirs, which also
addresses the limitations in these previous studies by ensuring enhanced
testing, evaluation, and reproducibility. The tool was evaluated using various
cycle-based reservoir topologies and demonstrated stable performance across a
range of configurations in memory capacity tasks.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces ChemReservoir, an open-source framework for chemically-inspired reservoir computing, designed to overcome limitations in existing DNA-chemistry-based tools.
AI.motivation: Existing DNA chemistry-inspired reservoir tools are limited in their usability and maintenance, creating a need for a more general and reproducible open-source framework.
AI.method: The paper presents ChemReservoir, a general framework for constructing and analyzing chemically-inspired reservoirs, with a focus on testing, evaluation, and reproducibility.
AI.result: ChemReservoir demonstrated stable performance in memory capacity tasks across various cycle-based reservoir topologies.
AI.conclusion: ChemReservoir addresses limitations in prior tools by providing a versatile and robust framework for chemically-inspired reservoir computing.

title: Reason-to-Recommend: Using Interaction-of-Thought Reasoning to Enhance LLM Recommendation
summary:
Driven by advances in Large Language Models (LLMs), integrating them into
recommendation tasks has gained interest due to their strong semantic
understanding and prompt flexibility. Prior work encoded user-item interactions
or metadata into prompts for recommendations. In parallel, LLM reasoning,
boosted by test-time scaling and reinforcement learning, has excelled in fields
like mathematics and code, where reasoning traces and correctness signals are
clear, enabling high performance and interpretability. However, directly
applying these reasoning methods to recommendation is ineffective because user
feedback is implicit and lacks reasoning supervision. To address this, we
propose $\textbf{R2Rec}$, a reasoning-enhanced recommendation framework that
samples interaction chains from the user-item graph and converts them into
structured interaction-of-thoughts via a progressive masked prompting strategy,
with each thought representing stepwise reasoning grounded in interaction
context. This allows LLMs to simulate step-by-step decision-making based on
implicit patterns. We design a two-stage training pipeline: supervised
fine-tuning teaches basic reasoning from high-quality traces, and reinforcement
learning refines reasoning via reward signals, alleviating sparse explicit
supervision. Experiments on three real-world datasets show R2Rec outperforms
classical and LLM-based baselines with an average $\textbf{10.48%}$ improvement
in HitRatio@1 and $\textbf{131.81%}$ gain over the original LLM. Furthermore,
the explicit reasoning chains enhance interpretability by revealing the
decision process. Our code is available at:
https://anonymous.4open.science/r/R2Rec-7C5D.

AI.tldr: R2Rec, a reasoning-driven framework, utilizes interaction chains and progressive masked prompting to enhance recommendations using LLMs. It significantly improves accuracy and interpretability compared to baselines.
AI.motivation: To improve recommendation systems by leveraging LLMs' reasoning abilities and addressing their limitations in dealing with implicit user feedback.
AI.method: The R2Rec framework uses interaction chains from user-item graphs transformed into structured reasoning sequences. It trains LLMs via a two-stage process: supervised fine-tuning for basic reasoning and reinforcement learning with reward signals to refine decisions.
AI.result: Experiments on three datasets demonstrate an average 10.48% improvement in HitRatio@1 and a 131.81% gain over the original LLM, showcasing R2Rec's superiority over traditional and previous LLM methods.
AI.conclusion: R2Rec effectively integrates reasoning into recommendations, enhancing both performance and interpretability. It highlights the scalability and depth LLMs can bring to recommendation systems.

title: Survey on the Evaluation of Generative Models in Music
summary:
Research on generative systems in music has seen considerable attention and
growth in recent years. A variety of attempts have been made to systematically
evaluate such systems. We provide an interdisciplinary review of the common
evaluation targets, methodologies, and metrics for the evaluation of both
system output and model usability, covering subjective and objective
approaches, qualitative and quantitative approaches, as well as empirical and
computational methods. We discuss the advantages and challenges of such
approaches from a musicological, an engineering, and an HCI perspective.

AI.tldr: The study reviews evaluation approaches for generative music systems, discussing methodologies and metrics from multiple disciplinary perspectives.
AI.motivation: To systematically evaluate generative music systems as they gain increasing attention and application.
AI.method: An interdisciplinary review of evaluation methods, spanning subjective, objective, qualitative, quantitative, empirical, and computational approaches.
AI.result: Identified advantages and challenges of existing evaluation strategies across musicology, engineering, and HCI domains.
AI.conclusion: Comprehensive evaluation requires considering perspectives and methodologies from multiple disciplines to assess generative music systems effectively.

title: Estimating properties of a homogeneous bounded soil using machine learning models
summary:
This work focuses on estimating soil properties from water moisture
measurements. We consider simulated data generated by solving the
initial-boundary value problem governing vertical infiltration in a
homogeneous, bounded soil profile, with the usage of the Fokas method. To
address the parameter identification problem, which is formulated as a
two-output regression task, we explore various machine learning models. The
performance of each model is assessed under different data conditions: full,
noisy, and limited. Overall, the prediction of diffusivity $D$ tends to be more
accurate than that of hydraulic conductivity $K.$ Among the models considered,
Support Vector Machines (SVMs) and Neural Networks (NNs) demonstrate the
highest robustness, achieving near-perfect accuracy and minimal errors.

AI.tldr: This study uses machine learning models to predict soil properties like diffusivity and hydraulic conductivity from water moisture data.
AI.motivation: Accurate estimation of soil properties is critical for understanding water infiltration and its effects, aiming to improve predictions under varying conditions.
AI.method: Simulated data generated from a boundary value problem using the Fokas method was analyzed using machine learning models (SVMs and NNs), under conditions like full, noisy, and limited datasets.
AI.result: SVMs and NNs showed highest accuracy and robustness, with diffusivity predictions being more reliable than hydraulic conductivity predictions.
AI.conclusion: SVMs and NNs are effective for predicting soil properties, offering near-perfect accuracy under diverse data conditions.

title: Interpretable LLMs for Credit Risk: A Systematic Review and Taxonomy
comment:
20 pages, 6 figures, preprint under review at Information Processing
  & Management
summary:
Large Language Models (LLM), which have developed in recent years, enable
credit risk assessment through the analysis of financial texts such as analyst
reports and corporate disclosures. This paper presents the first systematic
review and taxonomy focusing on LLMbased approaches in credit risk estimation.
We determined the basic model architectures by selecting 60 relevant papers
published between 2020-2025 with the PRISMA research strategy. And we examined
the data used for scenarios such as credit default prediction and risk
analysis. Since the main focus of the paper is interpretability, we classify
concepts such as explainability mechanisms, chain of thought prompts and
natural language justifications for LLM-based credit models. The taxonomy
organizes the literature under four main headings: model architectures, data
types, explainability mechanisms and application areas. Based on this analysis,
we highlight the main future trends and research gaps for LLM-based credit
scoring systems. This paper aims to be a reference paper for artificial
intelligence and financial researchers.

AI.tldr: This paper systematically reviews 60 research papers (2020-2025) on using Large Language Models (LLMs) in credit risk assessment, presenting a taxonomy focused on model architectures, data types, explainability mechanisms, and applications.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the growing potential of LLMs in financial applications, specifically credit risk assessment, and to provide an organized reference for researchers in AI and finance.
AI.method: The study conducted a systematic review using the PRISMA strategy, focused on relevant literature, and categorized key insights into a taxonomy based on four domains: model architecture, data types, explainability mechanisms, and application areas.
AI.result: The paper identifies insights from 60 studies, organizes them into a comprehensive taxonomy, and examines trends and gaps in LLM-based credit risk applications.
AI.conclusion: The research underscores the importance of interpretability in LLM-based credit risk models and offers a roadmap for future research in this interdisciplinary domain.

title: GARG-AML against Smurfing: A Scalable and Interpretable Graph-Based Framework for Anti-Money Laundering
summary:
Money laundering poses a significant challenge as it is estimated to account
for 2%-5% of the global GDP. This has compelled regulators to impose stringent
controls on financial institutions. One prominent laundering method for evading
these controls, called smurfing, involves breaking up large transactions into
smaller amounts. Given the complexity of smurfing schemes, which involve
multiple transactions distributed among diverse parties, network analytics has
become an important anti-money laundering tool. However, recent advances have
focused predominantly on black-box network embedding methods, which has
hindered their adoption in businesses. In this paper, we introduce GARG-AML, a
novel graph-based method that quantifies smurfing risk through a single
interpretable metric derived from the structure of the second-order transaction
network of each individual node in the network. Unlike traditional methods,
GARG-AML strikes an effective balance among computational efficiency, detection
power and transparency, which enables its integration into existing AML
workflows. To enhance its capabilities, we combine the GARG-AML score
calculation with different tree-based methods and also incorporate the scores
of the node's neighbours. An experimental evaluation on large-scale synthetic
and open-source networks demonstrate that the GARG-AML outperforms the current
state-of-the-art smurfing detection methods. By leveraging only the adjacency
matrix of the second-order neighbourhood and basic network features, this work
highlights the potential of fundamental network properties towards advancing
fraud detection.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces GARG-AML, a novel and interpretable graph-based method to quantify smurfing risk in money laundering through second-order network analytics. It is computationally efficient and outperforms state-of-the-art methods under experimental evaluation.
AI.motivation: Money laundering remains a global issue, representing 2%-5% of the GDP, with smurfing being a common laundering tactic. Current solutions rely on black-box models, hindering transparency and adoption especially in business processes.
AI.method: The authors develop GARG-AML, an interpretable method leveraging second-order transaction networks to assess smurfing risks. GARG-AML integrates with tree-based methods and considers neighbor scores while working with adjacency matrices and basic network features.
AI.result: Experimental evaluations on synthetic and open-source datasets show that GARG-AML surpasses existing tools in detecting smurfing schemes.
AI.conclusion: GARG-AML combines efficiency, transparency, and detection power, offering a practical solution for AML workflows. It underscores the value of leveraging fundamental network properties for fraud detection.

title: Intentionally Unintentional: GenAI Exceptionalism and the First Amendment
summary:
This paper challenges the assumption that courts should grant First Amendment
protections to outputs from large generative AI models, such as GPT-4 and
Gemini. We argue that because these models lack intentionality, their outputs
do not constitute speech as understood in the context of established legal
precedent, so there can be no speech to protect. Furthermore, if the model
outputs are not speech, users cannot claim a First Amendment speech right to
receive the outputs. We also argue that extending First Amendment rights to AI
models would not serve the fundamental purposes of free speech, such as
promoting a marketplace of ideas, facilitating self-governance, or fostering
self-expression. In fact, granting First Amendment protections to AI models
would be detrimental to society because it would hinder the government's
ability to regulate these powerful technologies effectively, potentially
leading to the unchecked spread of misinformation and other harms.

AI.tldr: The paper argues that outputs from generative AI should not receive First Amendment protections because they lack intentionality and granting such rights undermines societal and regulatory goals.
AI.motivation: To challenge the assumption and explore the implications of granting First Amendment protections to generative AI outputs.
AI.method: The authors analyze the legal precedent, the philosophical basis of free speech, and societal impacts of extending speech rights to AI models.
AI.result: They conclude that AI outputs do not qualify as speech under the First Amendment and extending such protections would harm regulatory oversight and societal well-being.
AI.conclusion: The paper finds that granting First Amendment protections to generative AI would neither align with legal precedent nor benefit society, instead enabling harms like misinformation.

title: BridgeNet: A Hybrid, Physics-Informed Machine Learning Framework for Solving High-Dimensional Fokker-Planck Equations
summary:
BridgeNet is a novel hybrid framework that integrates convolutional neural
networks with physics-informed neural networks to efficiently solve non-linear,
high-dimensional Fokker-Planck equations (FPEs). Traditional PINNs, which
typically rely on fully connected architectures, often struggle to capture
complex spatial hierarchies and enforce intricate boundary conditions. In
contrast, BridgeNet leverages adaptive CNN layers for effective local feature
extraction and incorporates a dynamically weighted loss function that
rigorously enforces physical constraints. Extensive numerical experiments
across various test cases demonstrate that BridgeNet not only achieves
significantly lower error metrics and faster convergence compared to
conventional PINN approaches but also maintains robust stability in
high-dimensional settings. This work represents a substantial advancement in
computational physics, offering a scalable and accurate solution methodology
with promising applications in fields ranging from financial mathematics to
complex system dynamics.

AI.tldr: BridgeNet integrates CNNs with PINNs to solve challenging Fokker-Planck equations efficiently, outperforming traditional PINNs.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address limitations of traditional Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) in capturing complex spatial hierarchies and enforcing intricate boundary conditions in high-dimensional non-linear Fokker-Planck equations.
AI.method: BridgeNet combines adaptive CNN layers for local feature extraction and a dynamically weighted loss function to rigorously enforce physical constraints.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show BridgeNet offers lower error, faster convergence, and robust stability in high-dimensional contexts compared to conventional PINNs.
AI.conclusion: BridgeNet is a scalable and accurate computational framework with potential applications in diverse fields like financial mathematics and complex system dynamics.

title: Teaming in the AI Era: AI-Augmented Frameworks for Forming, Simulating, and Optimizing Human Teams
comment: 5 pages, UMAP 25, June 16_19, 2025, New York City, NY, USA
summary:
Effective teamwork is essential across diverse domains. During the team
formation stage, a key challenge is forming teams that effectively balance user
preferences with task objectives to enhance overall team satisfaction. In the
team performing stage, maintaining cohesion and engagement is critical for
sustaining high team performance. However, existing computational tools and
algorithms for team optimization often rely on static data inputs, narrow
algorithmic objectives, or solutions tailored for specific contexts, failing to
account for the dynamic interplay of team members personalities, evolving
goals, and changing individual preferences. Therefore, teams may encounter
member dissatisfaction, as purely algorithmic assignments can reduce members
commitment to team goals or experience suboptimal engagement due to the absence
of timely, personalized guidance to help members adjust their behaviors and
interactions as team dynamics evolve. Ultimately, these challenges can lead to
reduced overall team performance. My Ph.D. dissertation aims to develop
AI-augmented team optimization frameworks and practical systems that enhance
team satisfaction, engagement, and performance. First, I propose a team
formation framework that leverages a multi-armed bandit algorithm to
iteratively refine team composition based on user preferences, ensuring
alignment between individual needs and collective team goals to enhance team
satisfaction. Second, I introduce tAIfa (Team AI Feedback Assistant), an
AI-powered system that utilizes large language models (LLMs) to deliver
immediate, personalized feedback to both teams and individual members,
enhancing cohesion and engagement. Finally, I present PuppeteerLLM, an
LLM-based simulation framework that simulates multi-agent teams to model
complex team dynamics within realistic environments, incorporating task-driven
collaboration and long-term coordination.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces AI frameworks for better team formation, engagement, and performance by using multi-armed bandit algorithms, personalized feedback tools, and LLM-based simulations.
AI.motivation: Current computational tools for team optimization inadequately handle dynamic team compositions, evolving goals, and personal preferences, often leading to dissatisfaction and reduced team performance.
AI.method: The author proposes three solutions: a multi-armed bandit algorithm for optimizing team formation, an AI-powered feedback assistant (tAIfa) for engagement, and PuppeteerLLM, a simulation framework using large language models.
AI.result: The proposed frameworks aim to optimize team satisfaction, engagement, and cohesion by aligning individual preferences with team goals and offering real-time feedback and advanced simulations of team dynamics.
AI.conclusion: The research enhances AI's capability to address challenges in team formation and operation, promising improvements in team satisfaction, engagement, and overall performance.

title: Optical Physics-Based Generative Models
summary:
This paper establishes a comprehensive mathematical framework connecting
optical physics equations to generative models, demonstrating how light
propagation dynamics inspire powerful artificial intelligence approaches. We
analyze six fundamental optical equations, comparing linear models (Helmholtz,
dissipative wave, and Eikonal equations) with their nonlinear extensions
incorporating Kerr effects, cubic-quintic nonlinearities, and
intensity-dependent refractive indices. Our nonlinear optical models reveal
remarkable capabilities through natural self-organization principles. The
nonlinear Helmholtz model achieves 40-60% parameter reduction while maintaining
superior mode separation via self-focusing phenomena. The cubic-quintic
dissipative wave model prevents mode collapse through balanced
attractive-repulsive interactions, enabling stable soliton formation with
20-40% improved coverage. The intensity-dependent Eikonal model creates
adaptive pathways that dynamically respond to content, providing enhanced
controllability in conditional generation. Experimental validation demonstrates
consistent superiority over linear predecessors and traditional generative
approaches. The nonlinear Helmholtz model achieves FID scores of 0.0089 versus
1.0909 for linear versions, while the cubic-quintic model reaches 0.0156 FID
with exceptional stability. Memory usage drops 40-60% and training time
improves 30-50% due to inherent nonlinear stability properties. The framework
enables bidirectional benefits, advancing both generative AI and optical
physics through novel approaches to soliton analysis, wavefront control, and
refractive index reconstruction with 95% accuracy. This work reveals deep
connections between physical self-organization and artificial intelligence,
opening pathways toward efficient optical computing implementations.

AI.tldr: This paper integrates optical physics equations with generative AI models, demonstrating superior performance and efficiency using nonlinear optical principles.
AI.motivation: To bridge the gap between optical physics and generative AI, leveraging the self-organization principles in optical systems to enhance generative model efficiency and performance.
AI.method: Analyzed six optical equations (linear and nonlinear), developed generative models inspired by these equations, and conducted experimental validation to compare performance metrics like FID scores, memory usage, and training time.
AI.result: The nonlinear models exhibited improved performance, with reductions in parameter use (40-60%), memory usage (40-60%), and training time (30-50%). The models achieved superior FID scores and enhanced stability compared to linear and traditional methods.
AI.conclusion: This study establishes that optical self-organization principles, particularly in nonlinear systems, can significantly advance generative AI, also enhancing optical physics methodologies with potential applications in efficient optical computing.

title: Solving engineering eigenvalue problems with neural networks using the Rayleigh quotient
summary:
From characterizing the speed of a thermal system's response to computing
natural modes of vibration, eigenvalue analysis is ubiquitous in engineering.
In spite of this, eigenvalue problems have received relatively little treatment
compared to standard forward and inverse problems in the physics-informed
machine learning literature. In particular, neural network discretizations of
solutions to eigenvalue problems have seen only a handful of studies. Owing to
their nonlinearity, neural network discretizations prevent the conversion of
the continuous eigenvalue differential equation into a standard discrete
eigenvalue problem. In this setting, eigenvalue analysis requires more
specialized techniques. Using a neural network discretization of the
eigenfunction, we show that a variational form of the eigenvalue problem called
the "Rayleigh quotient" in tandem with a Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization
procedure is a particularly simple and robust approach to find the eigenvalues
and their corresponding eigenfunctions. This method is shown to be useful for
finding sets of harmonic functions on irregular domains, parametric and
nonlinear eigenproblems, and high-dimensional eigenanalysis. We also discuss
the utility of harmonic functions as a spectral basis for approximating
solutions to partial differential equations. Through various examples from
engineering mechanics, the combination of the Rayleigh quotient objective,
Gram-Schmidt procedure, and the neural network discretization of the
eigenfunction is shown to offer unique advantages for handling continuous
eigenvalue problems.

AI.tldr: This paper explores a neural network-based approach to tackle eigenvalue problems, applying a variational technique called Rayleigh quotient combined with Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization.
AI.motivation: Eigenvalue problems, crucial in engineering and physics, have received limited attention in physics-informed machine learning, compared to traditional forward and inverse problems.
AI.method: The study uses neural network discretizations combined with the Rayleigh quotient and Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization procedure to address eigenvalue problems, including irregular domains and high-dimensions.
AI.result: The proposed technique proves effective for solving diverse eigenvalue problems, such as harmonic functions, parametric, nonlinear, and high-dimensional challenges.
AI.conclusion: The method demonstrates simplicity, robustness, and unique advantages for handling continuous eigenvalue problems across various engineering mechanics scenarios.

title: Non-linear Multi-objective Optimization with Probabilistic Branch and Bound
summary:
A multiple objective simulation optimization algorithm named Multiple
Objective Probabilistic Branch and Bound with Single Observation (MOPBnB(so))
is presented for approximating the Pareto optimal set and the associated
efficient frontier for stochastic multi-objective optimization problems.
MOPBnB(so) evaluates a noisy function exactly once at any solution and uses
neighboring solutions to estimate the objective functions, in contrast to a
variant that uses multiple replications at a solution to estimate the objective
functions. A finite-time performance analysis for deterministic multi-objective
problems provides a bound on the probability that MOPBnB(so) captures the
Pareto optimal set. Asymptotic convergence of MOPBnB(so) on stochastic problems
is derived, in that the algorithm captures the Pareto optimal set and the
estimations converge to the true objective function values. Numerical results
reveal that the variant with multiple replications is extremely intensive in
terms of computational resources compared to MOPBnB(so). In addition, numerical
results show that MOPBnB(so) outperforms a genetic algorithm NSGA-II on test
problems.

AI.tldr: MOPBnB(so) is introduced for stochastic multi-objective optimization, offering better computational efficiency and outperforming NSGA-II.
AI.motivation: To address the computational intensity of evaluating noisy functions multiple times in stochastic multi-objective optimization problems.
AI.method: Developed the Multiple Objective Probabilistic Branch and Bound with Single Observation (MOPBnB(so)), which evaluates a noisy function once and uses neighboring solutions for estimates.
AI.result: Finite-time performance analysis shows bounds on capturing the Pareto optimal set, asymptotic convergence on stochastic problems, and computational advantages over multiple-replication methods and NSGA-II.
AI.conclusion: MOPBnB(so) is an efficient method for approximating the Pareto optimal set, offering accuracy and computational advantages over existing algorithms.

title: MVP-Shapley: Feature-based Modeling for Evaluating the Most Valuable Player in Basketball
summary:
The burgeoning growth of the esports and multiplayer online gaming community
has highlighted the critical importance of evaluating the Most Valuable Player
(MVP). The establishment of an explainable and practical MVP evaluation method
is very challenging. In our study, we specifically focus on play-by-play data,
which records related events during the game, such as assists and points. We
aim to address the challenges by introducing a new MVP evaluation framework,
denoted as \oursys, which leverages Shapley values. This approach encompasses
feature processing, win-loss model training, Shapley value allocation, and MVP
ranking determination based on players' contributions. Additionally, we
optimize our algorithm to align with expert voting results from the perspective
of causality. Finally, we substantiated the efficacy of our method through
validation using the NBA dataset and the Dunk City Dynasty dataset and
implemented online deployment in the industry.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an MVP evaluation framework, \oursys, which employs Shapley values to assess player contributions using play-by-play game data. It has been validated with datasets and deployed online.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of creating an explainable and practical MVP evaluation method for esports and multiplayer online gaming.
AI.method: The framework processes features, trains a win-loss model, allocates Shapley values to measure contributions, and ranks players as MVPs. Additionally, it optimizes results to align with expert voting using a causal approach.
AI.result: The method was validated using the NBA dataset and the Dunk City Dynasty dataset, demonstrating its efficacy and real-world applicability.
AI.conclusion: \oursys effectively evaluates MVPs in gaming scenarios, integrates expert voting perspectives, and has been successfully deployed in the industry.

title: Can Artificial Intelligence Trade the Stock Market?
summary:
The paper explores the use of Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) in stock
market trading, focusing on two algorithms: Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN) and
Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) and compares them with Buy and Hold
benchmark. It evaluates these algorithms across three currency pairs, the S&P
500 index and Bitcoin, on the daily data in the period of 2019-2023. The
results demonstrate DRL's effectiveness in trading and its ability to manage
risk by strategically avoiding trades in unfavorable conditions, providing a
substantial edge over classical approaches, based on supervised learning in
terms of risk-adjusted returns.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates two Deep Reinforcement Learning algorithms, DDQN and PPO, for stock market trading across diverse assets, showing their effectiveness against traditional Buy and Hold strategies.
AI.motivation: To explore how DRL can enhance trading strategies and risk management over classical supervised learning methods in financial markets.
AI.method: Comparison of DDQN and PPO algorithms against Buy and Hold strategy across various assets including currency pairs, S&P 500, and Bitcoin, using daily data (2019-2023).
AI.result: DRL algorithms demonstrated their ability to outperform classical strategies by strategically avoiding risky trades, offering better risk-adjusted returns.
AI.conclusion: DRL-based trading methods provide a significant advantage over traditional approaches in terms of efficiency and risk management.

title: Improving AI-generated music with user-guided training
summary:
AI music generation has advanced rapidly, with models like diffusion and
autoregressive algorithms enabling high-fidelity outputs. These tools can alter
styles, mix instruments, or isolate them. Since sound can be visualized as
spectrograms, image-generation algorithms can be applied to generate novel
music. However, these algorithms are typically trained on fixed datasets, which
makes it challenging for them to interpret and respond to user input
accurately. This is especially problematic because music is highly subjective
and requires a level of personalization that image generation does not provide.
In this work, we propose a human-computation approach to gradually improve the
performance of these algorithms based on user interactions. The
human-computation element involves aggregating and selecting user ratings to
use as the loss function for fine-tuning the model. We employ a genetic
algorithm that incorporates user feedback to enhance the baseline performance
of a model initially trained on a fixed dataset. The effectiveness of this
approach is measured by the average increase in user ratings with each
iteration. In the pilot test, the first iteration showed an average rating
increase of 0.2 compared to the baseline. The second iteration further improved
upon this, achieving an additional increase of 0.39 over the first iteration.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes using human-computation and genetic algorithms to enhance AI-generated music via user feedback.
AI.motivation: Music generation models often lack personalization due to training on fixed datasets, which limits their ability to cater to subjective user preferences.
AI.method: The research introduces a genetic algorithm leveraging user ratings as a loss function to fine-tune AI models trained on fixed datasets.
AI.result: In pilot tests, user ratings increased by 0.2 after the first iteration and by an additional 0.39 in the second iteration, indicating improvement through user feedback.
AI.conclusion: Integrating human-computation and feedback loops improves the personalization and performance of music AI algorithms.

title: EMBER2024 -- A Benchmark Dataset for Holistic Evaluation of Malware Classifiers
summary:
A lack of accessible data has historically restricted malware analysis
research, and practitioners have relied heavily on datasets provided by
industry sources to advance. Existing public datasets are limited by narrow
scope - most include files targeting a single platform, have labels supporting
just one type of malware classification task, and make no effort to capture the
evasive files that make malware detection difficult in practice. We present
EMBER2024, a new dataset that enables holistic evaluation of malware
classifiers. Created in collaboration with the authors of EMBER2017 and
EMBER2018, the EMBER2024 dataset includes hashes, metadata, feature vectors,
and labels for more than 3.2 million files from six file formats. Our dataset
supports the training and evaluation of machine learning models on seven
malware classification tasks, including malware detection, malware family
classification, and malware behavior identification. EMBER2024 is the first to
include a collection of malicious files that initially went undetected by a set
of antivirus products, creating a "challenge" set to assess classifier
performance against evasive malware. This work also introduces EMBER feature
version 3, with added support for several new feature types. We are releasing
the EMBER2024 dataset to promote reproducibility and empower researchers in the
pursuit of new malware research topics.

AI.tldr: EMBER2024 is a comprehensive malware dataset with over 3.2 million files covering six file formats, enabling a broader scope of malware analysis tasks and addressing gaps in previously available datasets.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to overcome the limitations of existing datasets that have narrow scopes, lack standardization for diverse malware classification tasks, and fail to include evasive malware varieties.
AI.method: The authors collaborated with creators of prior EMBER datasets, expanded the dataset to include hashes, metadata, feature vectors, and labels across multiple file formats, and introduced a "challenge" set of evasive files along with new feature types in EMBER version 3.
AI.result: EMBER2024 provides support for training and evaluating models on seven different malware tasks, boasts over 3.2 million representative files from six formats, and introduces the first "challenge" set for evasive malware classification.
AI.conclusion: The release of EMBER2024 promotes reproducibility in research and enables a more holistic evaluation of malware detection and classification technologies, inspiring advancements in the field.

title: Membership Inference Attacks on Sequence Models
comment:
Accepted to the 8th Deep Learning Security and Privacy Workshop
  (DLSP) workshop (best paper award)
summary:
Sequence models, such as Large Language Models (LLMs) and autoregressive
image generators, have a tendency to memorize and inadvertently leak sensitive
information. While this tendency has critical legal implications, existing
tools are insufficient to audit the resulting risks. We hypothesize that those
tools' shortcomings are due to mismatched assumptions. Thus, we argue that
effectively measuring privacy leakage in sequence models requires leveraging
the correlations inherent in sequential generation. To illustrate this, we
adapt a state-of-the-art membership inference attack to explicitly model
within-sequence correlations, thereby demonstrating how a strong existing
attack can be naturally extended to suit the structure of sequence models.
Through a case study, we show that our adaptations consistently improve the
effectiveness of memorization audits without introducing additional
computational costs. Our work hence serves as an important stepping stone
toward reliable memorization audits for large sequence models.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes improved methods to measure privacy leakage in sequence models like LLMs by using sequential data correlations and adapting existing attack techniques.
AI.motivation: To address the privacy leakage of sequence models, which can inadvertently memorize and reveal sensitive data, and resolve gaps in current auditing tools.
AI.method: Adapting a state-of-the-art membership inference attack to capture within-sequence correlations in sequence models.
AI.result: The adapted attack techniques showed consistent performance improvements in identifying memorization issues, without increasing computational costs.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights a pathway to better privacy leakage quantification, paving the way for reliable memorization audits in sequence models.

title: Trustworthiness Preservation by Copies of Machine Learning Systems
summary:
A common practice of ML systems development concerns the training of the same
model under different data sets, and the use of the same (training and test)
sets for different learning models. The first case is a desirable practice for
identifying high quality and unbiased training conditions. The latter case
coincides with the search for optimal models under a common dataset for
training. These differently obtained systems have been considered akin to
copies. In the quest for responsible AI, a legitimate but hardly investigated
question is how to verify that trustworthiness is preserved by copies. In this
paper we introduce a calculus to model and verify probabilistic complex queries
over data and define four distinct notions: Justifiably, Equally, Weakly and
Almost Trustworthy which can be checked analysing the (partial) behaviour of
the copy with respect to its original. We provide a study of the relations
between these notions of trustworthiness, and how they compose with each other
and under logical operations. The aim is to offer a computational tool to check
the trustworthiness of possibly complex systems copied from an original whose
behavour is known.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a framework to evaluate the trustworthiness of machine learning (ML) systems copied from original models using probabilistic queries and establishes four notions of trustworthiness.
AI.motivation: Assessing the trustworthiness of ML systems that are modified or duplicated is crucial in the context of responsible AI but remains underexplored.
AI.method: The authors propose a calculus to model and analyze probabilistic queries over data, defining four notions of trustworthiness for copied ML systems.
AI.result: The paper establishes the relationships and compositional properties among the four notions of trustworthiness, offering a structured approach to assess copied systems.
AI.conclusion: The proposed computational tool helps verify that the trustworthiness of ML system copies aligns with their original counterparts.

title: Robust Moment Identification for Nonlinear PDEs via a Neural ODE Approach
summary:
We propose a data-driven framework for learning reduced-order moment dynamics
from PDE-governed systems using Neural ODEs. In contrast to derivative-based
methods like SINDy, which necessitate densely sampled data and are sensitive to
noise, our approach based on Neural ODEs directly models moment trajectories,
enabling robust learning from sparse and potentially irregular time series.
Using as an application platform the nonlinear Schr\"{o}dinger equation, the
framework accurately recovers governing moment dynamics when closure is
available, even with limited and irregular observations. For systems without
analytical closure, we introduce a data-driven coordinate transformation
strategy based on Stiefel manifold optimization, enabling the discovery of
low-dimensional representations in which the moment dynamics become closed,
facilitating interpretable and reliable modeling. We also explore cases where a
closure model is not known, such as a Fisher-KPP reaction-diffusion system.
Here we demonstrate that Neural ODEs can still effectively approximate the
unclosed moment dynamics and achieve superior extrapolation accuracy compared
to physical-expert-derived ODE models. This advantage remains robust even under
sparse and irregular sampling, highlighting the method's robustness in
data-limited settings. Our results highlight the Neural ODE framework as a
powerful and flexible tool for learning interpretable, low-dimensional moment
dynamics in complex PDE-governed systems.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a novel Neural ODE-based framework to learn reduced-order dynamics from PDE systems, offering robustness in sparse and noisy data scenarios.
AI.motivation: Existing methods like SINDy require dense and clean data, making them impractical for real-world applications with sparse and irregular sampling.
AI.method: The authors leverage Neural ODEs to model moment trajectories and introduce a coordinate transformation via Stiefel manifold optimization for systems lacking analytical closure.
AI.result: The framework successfully recovers governing moment dynamics under sparse and irregular observations, showing superior extrapolation compared to expert-derived models.
AI.conclusion: Neural ODE-based approaches are effective for discovering interpretable, low-dimensional moment dynamics in complex systems, showcasing robustness and versatility in challenging data conditions.
